case_vignette: a 16-year-old male with past medical history of mitral valve prolapse presents for evaluation of loose skin. patient's parents report a several year history of stretchy skin, poor wound healing with some scars healing with thin overlying skin, and easy bruising. there is a family history of similar symptoms amongst other family members. physical examination reveals soft, significantly extensible skin diffusely, multiple linear scars with atrophic overlying pink patches, and white-yellow papules along the bilateral inner and outer calcaneus upon standing. the patient is able to touch the tip of his nose with his tongue.
question: What is the final diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Dermatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. Do not ask the same question multiple times. Ask different questions to cover more information. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I have stretchy skin, poor wound healing, and easy bruising.
Do you have any joint issues such as hypermobility or frequent dislocations?
I didn't mention having any joint issues like hypermobility or frequent dislocations.
Have you experienced any unusual scarring or soft, doughy skin?
Yes, some of my scars heal with thin overlying skin and my skin feels soft and significantly extensible.
Does anyone in your family have similar symptoms or have been diagnosed with a genetic condition?
Yes, there is a family history of similar symptoms among other family members.
**Final Diagnosis:** Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome
